title: faw-side-wind-farm-developers-criticise-sbc-turbines
story: THE developers of a proposed wind farm that was rejected by Borders councillors have accused local authorities of speaking ldquowith forked tongues.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning committee last week, members opposed plans to build a -turbine wind farmacross the region and Dumfries and Galloway.Following the decision, projects director at Community Windpower ndash which submitted the proposals for the Faw Side wind farm ndash says that ldquono one is standing up for the climate.ldquoItrsquos disappointing that local authorities are not properly recognising the Climate ChangeAct  and the legally binding targets it has set for Scotland, said Gillian Cropper, of Community Windpower.ldquoLocal authorities speak with forked tongues on the one hand declare their own climate emergency and set unrealistic net zero targets whilst objecting to pretty much every onshore wind scheme on visual grounds.:Man broke into Borders flat by climbing through window, say policeldquoPlanning committees donrsquot appear to be briefed ndash we question why ldquoAre the local authorities not aware of this climate law  Why is there no legal counsel title: watch-nicola-sturgeons-covid-briefing-holyrood
story: NICOLASturgeon is to givea statement on the progress of the fight against COVID- in the Scottish Parliament today.The First Minister is expected to announce a slight easing of the restrictions the whole country has been living under.Ms Sturgeon has hailed the "good progress" being made with the vaccination programme in full swing and infection rates dropping.So things could change in the days ahead.Why are restrictions easing On Friday, Ms Sturgeon said that ldquogreater normality is firmly on the horizon. This is because the R number -the number of people that one infected person will pass on a virus to, on average - is below the crucial one figure.Experts currently predict it is around . - . for the whole of the UK. Meanwhile,the number of Covid cases relative to the size of the population - the rate per , - has also fallen.Under this measure, most of Scotland would currently cross the threshold for level two restrictions from  April.Crucially, the number of positive tests has been falling below the  per centlevel the World Health Organisationconsiders the marker for a pandemic being under control. Last week, it averaged. per centof the,tests reported.Family meet-ups could be back on the cardsSo what could change today It is expected that restrictions will be eased - but only on the number of people who can meet up outdoors.This is because the chances of passing on the virus are greatly reduced - but not eliminated - in the fresh air.At present, only two people from two households are allowed to socialise outdoors in Scotland.:Controversial Borders housing development proposal rejected by councillors#This was due to increase to four people from two households from March , but this is expected to be brought forward as a result of progress in suppressing new cases.This will allow more people to meet friends and family and could allow children to take part in some sports.What  is in the pipeline With some primary school pupils back at school and the rest expected to join them next week, opening up classrooms will continue.By late April, the government hopes to move back to a local "levels" system of regional restrictions across Scotland, albeitwith tougher rules than before.When will the statement be made The First Ministerwill address the Scottish Parliament around .pm. Coverage will be screened live on the Scottish Parliaments online TV channeland live on BBC Scotland.What are the politicians saying Ms Sturgeonsaidshe was ldquohopeful the Scottish Government may be able to make some ldquorelatively minor, but I think important, changes in our ability to meet outdoors and also how young people are able to interact with their friends outdoors.Deputy First Minister John Swinney confirmed on Monday any changes to the current lockdown regime would be set out by Ms Sturgeon.John SwinneyMr Swinneyadded: ldquoThe First Minister has been clear that we will try to relax lockdown as quickly as we possibly can do, but we have to do it in a sustainable manner.:Coronavirus: Heres how many new cases the Borders recorded over the weekendldquoThat means taking the appropriate steps in the appropriate sequence to make sure we donrsquot run the risk of the virus running away from us again.Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross welcomed the plans, saying the government had not "given enough hope" to people when setting out its path for easing lockdown.

story: FIRST Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced changes to coronavirus lockdown restrictions in Scotland.From Friday , up to four people from up to two households will be allowed to meet up in any outdoor space for social and recreational purposes.This includes meeting in private gardens, although Ms Sturgeon stressed that people should only go indoors for essential purposes, such as to reach the back garden or use the toilet.From Friday, outdoor non-contact sport and organised group exercise will also be permitted for all adults, in groups of up to  people.Meanwhile, there will be changes to outdoor meetings for --year-olds.Up to four people from that age bracket will be permitted to meet, but with no restriction to the number of households.This means four people from four households aged between - can meet in an outdoor space, which Ms Sturgeon says will allow young people to see more of their friends.The First Minister said the Scottish Government were making the changes to improve peoples "wellbeing and quality of le" without having a big impact on infection rates.

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-announcement-nine-key-points-fm-outlines-rule-changes
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has outlined some key changes to lockdown in Scotland, to take place as early as this week.Speaking in the Scottish Parliament today, the First Minister set out some ldquomodest changes to allow for improved wellbeing ndash with ldquomore substantial changes due within the weeks ahead.She added thatthe data allows more relaxation of measures more quickly, the Scottish Government will ldquonot hesitate to bring changes forward.Here, we outline the key points from her statement.Easing of outdoor meet-up rulesScots will be able to meet in bigger groups from Friday, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister said four people from two households will now be able to meet outdoors from Friday.For children aged between  and , outdoor meetings will also be limited to four people, but these can be from up to four households.The First Minister also said that while travel restrictions cannot be lted for adults, they will be eased slightly for children taking part in sport where their club may be ldquoa bit outside their council area.Non-contact sport isbackOutdoor, non-contact sports for adults in groups of up to  will also be able to start again from Friday, Ms Sturgeon said.Return of communal worshipCommunal worship in Scotland will restart from March , Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister told MSPs the limit for services will rise from  people to  people.She said: ldquoThis is in time for Passover, Easter, Ramadan and Vaisakhi.ldquoIn addition, the limit on attendance at communal services will be increased from , which was the limit in place before lockdown, to  ndash assuming of course that a place of worship is spacious enough to accommodate that many people with two-metre physical distancing.ldquoI know that the restrictions on communal worship have been dficult for many people, despite the exceptional efforts made by faith groups to reach out to their communities.ldquoThis change is a proportionate step, which we believe can be achieved relatively safely, and which will hopefully enable more people to draw strength, comfort and inspiration from acts of collective worship.Acceleration of vaccine roll-outAn increase in supply will see a ldquovery signicant acceleration of the vaccination programme, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has said.Speaking to MSPs in Holyrood, Ms Sturgeon said a dip in supply should be resolved by the middle of this month.She said: ldquoFrom about the middle of March onwards, however, we expect supplies to pick up again. This will allow for a very signicant acceleration in the vaccination programme.ldquoIt is worth noting that some of these supplies will be of short-dated stock ndash in other words, they will be of vaccines which must be used very soon after they have been received.The Scottish Government will now start to invite people in priority lists eight and nine, which includes those aged between  and  years old, to receive their first dose.Easing of restrictions early The Scottish Government ldquowill not hesitate to ease restrictions earlierdata supports it, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister told MSPs on Tuesday: ldquoIf the data allows us to relax more restrictions more quickly than we have previously indicated, we will not hesitate to do so.ldquoIrsquom well aware of just how dficult continued restrictions are ndash and I know that they get harder rather than easier to bear, as time goes on.ldquoI also know ndash because I feel this too ndash that the progress on vaccination makes us even more impatient to reach the end of this ordeal as quickly as possible.ldquoBut I am certain that easing restrictions too quickly would be a mistake that we would regret.Vaccine progressAlmost % of Scotlandrsquos adult population has received the first dose of the Covid- vaccine, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister told MSPs that ldquogood progress was being made with the vaccination programme, which has inoculated almost . million people.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThere is already strong evidence that the vaccination programme has signicantly reduced deaths in care homes.ldquoStudies are also showing that vaccination ndash as well as reducing illness and death ndash can signicantly reduce transmission of the virus.ldquoWe, therefore, have increasing confidence that as more and more people acquire some protection through vaccination, we will be able to ease restrictions while still keeping the R number below .Anger over Rangers fan gatheringsNicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government could not ldquoturn a blind eye to the mass gathering of Rangers fans at the weekend.Addressing MSPs in Holyrood, the First Minister said: ldquoIt would be deeply unfaira selfish minority spoil that for the majority, and I hope that will not be the case.ldquoBut, given the fragility of the situation we face right now, we cannot simply turn a blind eye to what happened at the weekend and we wonrsquot.ldquoWe will report back in due course ndash and certainly ahead of the Old Firm match scheduled for March  ndash on the ious discussions taking place this week.Minute silenceMs Sturgeon said that plans are in place to commemorate the anniversary of lockdown in Scotland.She said these plans include a national silence on March  to pay tribue to those who lost their le to the pandemic.The latest casesScotland has recorded the deaths of  coronavirus patients and  new cases in the past  hours, according to Scottish vaccine as of Tuesday morning ndash an increase of , in a day ndash and , have received their second dose.

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeons-lockdown-exit-compares-rest-uk
story: Coronavirus lockdown restrictions continue to be relaxed in dferent stages across Scotland, England, Wales and Northern Ireland.Yesterday, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was the latest leader to announce further easing of measures, with Scots allowed to meet in bigger groups from Friday.Here is what we know about each UK nationsrsquo plans to exit lockdown:ScotlandScotlandrsquos stay-at-home order is expected to be lted from April  under a phased plan to lt lockdown, with the country moving back to a levels system of restrictions from April .However, Ms Sturgeon told the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday that up to four people from two households will be able to meet outdoors from Friday.For children aged between  and , outdoor meetings will also be limited to four people, but these can be from up to four households.Communal worship in Scotland will restart from March , with the limit for services rising from  people to .Ms Sturgeon initially said lockdown would ease in phases that are separated by at least three weeks and dependant on suppression of the virus continuing.The first phase began with the youngest children in Scotland ing to their classrooms on February  as schools reopened to more pupils.The second phase is set to take place no earlier than March , with older primary children expected toto school full time from that date, along with secondary school pupils getting some time back in the classroom.They are due tofull-time after the Easter holiday.It is hoped a further extension to outdoor mixing and more freedoms in retail will be put in place from April , with the stay-at-home order expected to be lted.Theto a levels system, with further allowances on the opening of places like gyms, hairdressers and hospitality, is currently expected on April .Ms Sturgeon said more details around the easing of restrictions will be issued in mid-March ndash adding that the Scottish Government lsquowill not hesitatersquo to accelerate changesthe data allows it.Scotland has been in national lockdown since January .EnglandAll pupils in all year groups ed to classrooms on March  with outdoor after-school sports and activities also allowed to restart.People are now permitted to have socially distanced one-to-one meetings with others outdoors in a public space.Care home residents are also allowed a single nominated visitor, who will be required to take a Covid test, wear personal protective equipment and keep physical contact to a minimum.Larger groups will be allowed to gather in parks and gardens from March .The ldquorule of six will , along with new measures allowing two households, totalling no more than six people, to meet.Outdoor organised sport will also .From April  at the earliest, shops, hairdressers, nail salons, libraries, outdoor attractions and outdoor hospitality venues such as beer gardens will be allowed to reopenTwo households, or groups of up to six people, will be allowed to mix indoors and limited crowds will be allowed at sporting events from May .All remaining restrictions on social contact could be lted from June , allowing for larger events to go ahead and nightclubs to reopen.WalesWales entered a national lockdown on December  ndash the earliest of any nation in the UK.The Welsh Government is to consider whether stay-at-home regulations can be lted in a review of the rules this week, the results of which will be announced on Friday.An easing of some restrictions saw pupils aged three to seven begin a phasedto classrooms on February .Minor changes to the rules on February  also allowed up to four people from two households to exercise together outdoors.From March , all primary school pupils, as well as older age groups in years  and  who have exams, could also the countryrsquos public health situation continues to improve.Northern IrelandLockdown restrictions were introduced in Northern Ireland on December , and have been extended to April  by the Stormont Executive.However, a review is due on March .Primary school pupils in year groups P to P ed to classrooms on Monday but are set to go back to remote learning after two weeks.On March , secondary school children in key exam years - will .The Executiversquos plan for gradually exiting lockdown does not include any target dates, with ministers saying decisions on moving between stages will be based on scientic and medical evidence.

title: peeblesshire-foodbank-manager-urges-people-get-touch
story: DURING the pandemic the need for food banks has increased ndash but not necessarily for those who have always struggled on low incomes or benefits. Reporter Hilary Scott tuned in to Innerleithenrsquos Community Council, where members got an eye-opening update on Peeblesshire Foodbank...The message could not be clearer from Peeblesshire Foodbank manager Fiona Dalgleish ndash ldquoIf yoursquore struggling, you donrsquot have to keep it a secret. Reach out in confidence and we will help you.There is no doubt that Fiona, who took up the appointment of development manager in December, is saddened by the poverty she has witnessed first-hand.Families are reportedly living in inadequate accommodation, barely able to pay the bills, let alone feed themselves or their children.Itrsquos the kind of deprivation that many people would perhaps not consider happening in a place like Peeblesshire, says Fiona.But it does, and since February last year the need for the food bank has increased by  per cent.:Council asks for opinions on reduced speed limit near PeeblesldquoItrsquos been really busy, said Fiona. ldquoHorribly, the biggest increase is for children, and thatrsquos gone up a lot.ldquoSo many families are using us.ldquoWersquove helped  families comprising of  people in the last eight months, thatrsquos a lot of people.Although the global race to vaccinate people continues, the negative economic impact will be felt by many for months to come.ldquoWith the pandemic, people have lost hours, theyrsquove lost their jobs, and I think when furlough ends itrsquos going to be really tough for people.ldquoAlso, therersquos the possibility the government might withdraw the pound per week top-up on Universal Credit.ldquoAlthough the pandemic may be receding, the consequences are not. I want everyone to know that wersquore here and wersquore prepared to support everyone that needs a helping hand, said Fiona.:Coronavirus: NHS chief warns COVID lsquohasnrsquot gone awayrsquo as Borders cases risePrior to the COVID-lockdown, there was a limit on the number of parcels people could receive from the Peeblesshire Foodbank, but the current crisis means that has now been lted.ldquoThe limit was four per year, but at the moment, because people are struggling, we donrsquot really have a limit, we will help people according to their need.Askedthere was anything that has surprised her since taking on the role, Fiona replied: ldquoThe poverty in this area is really well hidden, some of the housing has been absolutely shocking.ldquoSome of the private rentals are really in a bad way, and a couple of them have been shocking.ldquoThe level of poverty that people are in, when they donrsquot have carpets and lightshades, and their cooker is broken, and theyrsquove got little children.ldquoThere are a lot of people that really need help, but theyrsquore pretty well disguised.ldquoThis area is perceived as affluent to a greater extent, but within Peebles and Innerleithen therersquos pockets of real deprivation.:Coronavirus: Number of Borders deaths last week shown in latest statisticsFiona said that what people see on the surface in terms of materialism, is not all as it seems.ldquoUnderneath that therersquos a very dferent community, she added.The food bank is committed to helping people through this dficult time by putting meals on the table, but plans are in the pipeline to offer much more than a hot dinner.Fiona explained: ldquoOur plan this year, when the pandemic is over, is to create the food bank into something thatrsquos a bit more like a help hub.ldquoSo, at the moment, we just provide food, but obviously food is the solution to just one problem.ldquoIf yoursquore in crisis you probably need some advice and some support as well.ldquoWersquove moved into a new building which has got space for our warehouse and itrsquos got a meeting space as well, so wersquore going to be doing drop-in sessions with the Citizens Advice, as well as budgeting and debt management.ldquoThere is the capacity to offer advice and emotional support, so you can have a cup of tea and just get things off your chest.:Grass cutting at Borders cemeteries has been problematic, meeting hearsDesperately hoping to remove the stigma attached to using the food bank, Fiona added: ldquoI think that people, once theyrsquove made the commitment to contact the food bank, find itrsquos actually really liberating to know they can talk to us, because theyrsquove got over that hurdle, and they donrsquot have to keep it a secret that they need a proper helping hand.ldquoWersquove got lots of volunteers with experience in counselling and pastoral support, and thatrsquos the way we are going to go hopefully from May.One of the benefits from lockdown often touted is that people are able to save a little money, but leader of Scottish Borders Council Shona Haslam, says this isnrsquot the case.ldquoFor families, the food bill every week has doubled,not tripled, and has been a shock for a lot people. And also, with the bad weather, therersquos fuel poverty.ldquoHouseholders have had to put their heating on during the day and peoplesrsquo household budgets are so stretched.Mrs Haslam also highlighted that free school meals are available to people who qualy.Innerleithen Community Council has promised to help those in need within the community by directing them to services available.:Borders woman, , sets up region-wide raffle to raise awareness of diseaseFiona added: ldquoI know I have sounded very doom and gloom but one thing I have to say is, the support from the community has been incredible.ldquoWe get so many donations, people turning up every day with food, and it really is quite humbling how much people care about their community.Residents of Peeblesshire donrsquot need to take off their rose-tinted glasses to see the poverty on their doorstep.Their acknowledgement of it can be seen through their generosity of spirit, with donations in the overflowing foodbank crates of supermarkets.There are big plans to expand the services offered by Peeblesshire Foodbank, but right now, Fiona, and her army of volunteers, just want to make sure no family goes hungry, and people reach out for helpthey need it.If you, or anyone you know, is in need of help or advice please contact Peeblesshire Foodbank: website www.peeblesshire.foodbank.org.uk, tel   email info@peeblesshire.foodbank.org.uk,  Silverbirch Studios, Cavalry Park, Peebles, EH BU.

title: nicola-sturgeon-addresses-secret-hairdresser-claims-updates-reopening-date
story: NICOLA Sturgeon yesterday addressed claims she has a ldquosecret hairdresser, while providing an update to those desperate for a trim.Appearing in front of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Covid- Committee, the First Minister and chief medical officer Gregor Smith gave evidence on issues from vaccination to the countryrsquos easing of lockdown.During the session, Cowdenbeath MSP Annabelle Ewing asked the First Ministershe could provide a solid date for the reopening of hairdressers.It is currently hoped that when Scotland moves towards a levels system, currently planned for April , hairdressers and barbers could reopen.The First Minister has said that there will be no delay ldquoany longer than is necessary.Nicola Sturgeon addressed the secret hairdresser claimsShe told MSPs: "Im not able to give you the date.ldquoI can give you absolute % assurance though that I will not delay our ability to visit the hairdresser any longer than is necessary."Im saying that out of pure self-interest as anybody looking at me can see."She went on: "There are still conspiracy theories that circulate on social media from time to time that Ive got a secret hairdresser somewhere."I can say firstly that is not true, but secondly I dont know why anybody looking at me right now can reach that conclusion."No hairdresser is responsible or would take responsibility for this. So, hairdressers, just as quickly as its possible to do."The First Minister previously said in parliament that she hoped to ease lockdown restrictions sooner than expected ndash however this depended on the figures supporting that decision.

title: covid-scotland-lockdown-rules-outdoor-meetings-worship-sport-eased-today
story: Lockdown measures are set to be eased across Scotland today as the country progresses in the fight against coronavirus.While the majority of tough restrictions remain in place, Nicola Sturgeon confirmed yesterday that some changes will be allowed to take place.It comes following her announcement on Tuesday in the Scottish Parliament, following ldquogreat progress during lockdown.While admitting the changes are ldquorelatively minor, the changes are hoped to improve wellbeing.She also added that she would ldquonot hesitate to bring more changes forwardthe data allowed it.Here is what changes from today:Outdoor gatherings for adultsFrom today, up to four people from two households can meet outdoors. This is for recreational purposes as well as exercise, and can include private gardens.The First Minister also confirmed that members of the public can travel through someonersquos house in order to use the toilet or get to a private garden, but encouraged the public to act sensibly and stick to the social distancing rules.Outdoor gatherings for teenagersFour children aged between  and  can also meet outdoors in recreational settings, however they are not limited to two households. Therefore, four children from four households are allowed to meet up.SportOutdoor, non-contact sport and exercise are now permitted for adults ndash in groups up to  people.What  is yet to come Speaking in the Scottish Parliament yesterday, Ms Sturgeon told MSPs the Scottish Government ldquowill go ahead as planned with the next stage of the reopening of schools on Monday.On Tuesday, the First Minister is also set to announce changes to the levels system of coronavirus restrictions, which is due to come into force from the end of April.And, ldquoassuming no deterioration of the figures, communal worship will be able to resume from Friday, March .What  did the FMsay Marking the one-year anniversary of the World Health Organisationdeclaring Covid- a pandemic, Ms Sturgeon said there were grounds for optimism.ldquoThe last  months have been incredibly tough ndash unimaginably tough for everybody, she said.ldquoBut as I indicated on Tuesday, we do now have real grounds for optimism, albeit cautious optimism.ldquoCase numbers, hospitalisations and deaths have all fallen in recent weeks and when we publish the latest estimate of the R number later today we expect it to show that it remains below one.ldquoAnd, of course, the vaccination programme has given a first dose to % of the entire adult population and it is set to signicantly accelerate over the next few weeks.

title: human-remains-found-kent-identified-sarah-everard
story: The human remains found by police searching for Sarah Everard have been confirmed as hers, Scotland Yard has announced.On Wednesday night, Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick said unidentied human remains had been found in an area of woodland in Ashford, in Kent, by detectives investigating Ms Everardrsquos disappearance.Speaking today to reporters outside Scotland Yard, Assistant Commissioner Nick Ephgrave said the body found in woodland in Kent was that of Sarah Everard.He said: ldquoAs you know, on Wednesday evening detectives investigating the disappearance of Sarah Everard discovered a body secreted in woodland in Kent.ldquoThe body has now been recovered and formal identication procedure has now been undertaken.ldquoI can now confirm that it is the body of Sarah Everard.Mr Ephgrave said that Sarah Everardrsquos family had been told this ldquomost distressing news.The politan Police officer accused of her murder remains in custody, he added.On Thursday, the family of Sarah Everard paid tribute to her as a ldquoshining example to us all, describing her as a daughter and sister who ldquobrought so much joy to our lives.Her family said: ldquoOur beautul daughter Sarah was taken from us and we are appealing for any information that will help to solve this terrible crime.ldquoSarah was bright and beautul ndash a wonderful daughter and sister. She was kind and thoughtful, caring and dependable. She always put others first and had the most amazing sense of humour.ldquoShe was strong and principled and a shining example to us all. We are very proud of her and she brought so much joy to our lives.ldquoWe would like to thank our friends and family for all their support during this awful time and we would especially like to thank Sarahrsquos friends who are working tirelessly to help.

title: scottish-borders-councils-budget-proposals-announced
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas outlined its proposed budget for the coming year.Councillors will vote on the plans on Friday, March .But todaySBC organised an online briefing for the media, during which council leader Shona Haslam said the budget would ldquohelp the Borders build back better.Here we take you through some key points from the proposed budget.When is the Great Tapestry Centre opening Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the council had previously confirmed that the Great Tapestry Centre in Galashiels would not meet be ready in time for the planned spring opening.At the budget briefing, SBCrsquos executive director, Rob Dickson, said the building is ldquonearing completion.ldquoWersquove got a lot of work to do to complete the recruitment and training of staff, he said. ldquoAs things stand, we still hope to open it in the summer but wersquore not in a position yet to confirm a date.David Robertson, SBCrsquos chief financial officer, added that no projects have had to be dropped for this budget.Borders Railway extensionIt was announced in November last year that the funding for the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal would be accelerated, with the full deal signed off this month.At todayrsquos briefing, Mrs Haslam, of the Conservatives, said a feasibility study looking into cross-border railway extensions would be ldquoone of the first projects that gets off the ground.ldquoThatrsquos in the hands of Transport Scotland so they will be doing the feasibility study and we will be holding their feet to the fire to make sure that study is done as quickly as possible, said Mrs Haslam.Mrs Haslam added that the council is looking forward to the launch of the UK Governmentrsquos union connectivity review to ldquosupport our ambitions of the extension of the railway in this area.New jobs and job lossesAccording to Mr Robertson, around  new jobs across the council are set to be created in this new budget.That includes a new position to help the food growing strategy for the region, as well as the creation of a sustainability officer to reduce the councilrsquos carbon footprint.Regarding job losses, Mr Robertson said: ldquoI donrsquot think therersquos one specic area that wersquore really targeting in terms of post reductions, this is an ongoing process of transformation across the council.Replacing SBCrsquos diesel vehiclesAccording to the budget proposal, the council is dedicating up to pound million to replace its current diesel vehicle fleet with hybrid and electric alternatives.Mr Robertson said: ldquoWe have a signicant number of ageing vehicles at the moment.He added that a contract for the provision of cars and vans is due to end this year, leading to  small diesel vehicles being replaced with electric vehicles.ldquoWe currently run around  vehicles across the councilrsquos fleets so hopefully that gives you some sort of indication of timing, said Mr Robertson, in regards to when all vehicles will be replaced.Investment in road networkThe council has outlined plans for pound. million of investment to go into improving road networks in the Borders, with another pound, the following year.Mark Rowley, SBCrsquos executive member for finance, said the investment would be going into ldquotargeted schemes identied by the public and council officers.Mrs Haslam added: ldquoNo one is denying that our roads are an issue. They have been getting better.ldquoWe are investing more and more and more into our roads and into technology to fix the roads better.SBCrsquos leader said a list of the roads where the money will be invested will be released in the coming days so the public can see ldquowhere that money is going.Investment in flood protectionAccording to the council, pound million will be ploughed into a flood protection scheme in Hawick, with Newcastleton also set to receive some investment.Both areas have been affected by flooding recently.SavingsOverall, the council is aiming to make savings of pound. million in this budget.That includes pound, per annum of savings in relation to cutting down the councilrsquos carbon footprint.

title: pm-supports-national-day-reflection-anniversary-first-lockdown
story: The Prime Minister and other political leaders have backed plans to hold a national day of reflection marking the anniversary of the first coronavirus lockdown.The end of le charity Marie Curie is planning a day of reflection to remember those who have died for March  ndash exactly a year since the UK was first told to stay at home.It will include a minutersquos silence at pm followed by a bell toll, and people are being encouraged to stand on their doorsteps at pm with phones, candles and torches to signy a ldquobeacon of remembrance.Prominent buildings and landmarks will also be lit up across the UK.On  March, were inviting you to take a minute to reflect and a moment to connect as part of a National #DayOfReflection.Join the minutes silence at  noon one month from now to show your support for the millions of people whove been bereaved: https:t.co HWexpcDCJpic NpsTZVKLmdash Marie CurieFebruary , More than  care organisations, charities,#businesses, emergency services,#public sector bodies and#community groups support the idea.The latest figures from the Office for National Statistics show , deaths had occurred in the UK by February  where Covid- was mentioned on the death certicate.Boris Johnson said he will observe the minutersquos silence at noon privately, while the head of the NHS Sir Simon Stevens has also leant his support.Mr Johnson said: ldquoThis has been an incredibly dficult year for our country. My thoughts are with all those who have lost loved ones, and who have not been able to pay tribute to them in the way they would have wanted.ldquoAs we continue to make progress against the virus, I want to thank people for the sacrices they continue to make, and hope they can look forward to being reunited with loved ones as restrictions are cautiously eased."The National #DayOfReflectionwill be friends, neighbours and communities have come together to help each other through the nationrsquos worst ordeal since the Second World War.ldquoWhile we need continuing vigilance against this virus, the remarkable NHS vaccination programme now brings hope of better times to come.Labour leader Sir Keir#Starmer, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford also Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Perth-based Kaya Fraser was chosen by the Mount Stuart Trust as their Emerging AIR for , an annual opportunity for a recent graduate to create a new socially engaged artwork in collaboration with communities living on the island.The artist is asking participants to phone her, via a landline installed in the kitchen in her home, to give her an update on the everyday how they are feeling and spending their time and to tell her what island le is like for them during more normal times. The conversations, Kaya hopes, will feel like the discussion that would usually evolve over a cup of tea or an evening pint.Kaya, who begins her residency this month, will record the conversations which will be stitched together as a sound-based artwork called Milk + Two Sugars which will eventually be exhibited on the island for local audiences to engage with and listen to.Over the last few weeks, invitations have been extended to the local residentsin the communities of The Bush and Ballochgoy. To take part they need only call   armed with a ‘cuppa’ of their choosing.The phoneline will be open to two people per day between am-pm on Thursday March  and Friday th, Thursday March  and Friday th. An answer phone message will be available in between times for people to register their interest in taking part.Kaya, who graduated from Duncan of Jordanstone in  with BA Hons First Class in Art and Philosophy in , said: #I begin this residency with a strong nostalgic feeling of connection to Rothesay even though only knowing it through family anecdotes of holidays there. I hope this residency extends these memories into my own stories of the people and stories I come to meet.#With Milk + Two Sugars, I aim to extend these connections beyond a screen and focus on the house phone as my source of extension. Edward and Mary were married in Knocknow, Southend, on October  .Their son, also named Edward, who was born in Southend on August  , travelled from West Virginia to Washington in the s and was one of the founders of a settlement which remains to this day.The village was founded in  when pioneers settled on its tide-swept flats and began to reclaim the land from the sea.#Washington Ed#, as he became known to the West Virginia McTaggarts, moved to the area in , and built a homestead on  acres of land, floating the timber for his home across the land at high tide.As others moved to the area and the settlement expanded, it was decided that a post office was required. Ed called a meeting at his home on March   to discuss the matter, with  settlers in attendance.A petition was drawn up and signed, asking for the creation of a post office with Ed as postmaster. He suggested naming the settlement Edison in honour of the inventor Thomas Edison.This led to the establishment in  of a trading post on land donated by Ed. In around , Edison#s first hotel was built on a small section of Ed#s land adjoining that on which the store stood.In , Ed married Mary Judson whose parents, Phoebe and Holden Judson, founded the city of Lynden in Washington. He is absolutely right, it has been a fantastic achievement, but to then go on to use this success to denigrate the EU#s vaccine programme is crass and over simplistic.Our success is an illusion until both doses of vaccine are administered, crowing about vaccines when only . per cent of the UK population has had the vital second jag, compared, for example, to . per cent in Denmark, is both presumptuous and inappropriate.Mr Newall goes on to assert that Scotland has a deficit that will prevent Scotland re-entering the EU, without of course mentioning the elephant in the room, the UK#s ruinous £ trillion # and increasing # debt. Unionists need to get their own house in order before lecturing anyone .Of course, legally, Scotland has no #deficit# or #debt#. How can a country with virtually no borrowing ability have a debt  What Scotland does have is a notional #debt#, the price of Westminster failure within the UK, where spending outwith Scotland#s control is assigned to Scotland, such as Trident, HS and London’s Crossrail. Spending that Scots taxpayers cough up for.Indeed,Courier readers start counting now at the rate of one a second, they#ll reach the number of pounds spent on Boris Johnson’s failed Track and Trace system at about .am on April  in the year . Readers may well wonder where the money went and why this is being loaded on to Scotland#s ledger.Straight from the #Better Together# playbook, Mr Newall brings up the hoary old #Spanish veto# myth. The truth is that Spain has no issue with an independent Scotland in the EU so long as this is within the framework of the UK constitution # which it is.Unlike Catalonia#s predicament, Scotland is not a #region# of the UK, there is no constitutional prohibition on independence votes or indeed of Scotland abrogating the  Treaty of Union with England.This is why successive prime ministers, from Margaret Thatcher to David Cameron, have repeatedly recognised the right of the Scottish people to independence # and why Boris Johnson#s oafish #No# will run into the sand.Mr Newall and I will never agree but that is the essence of democracy, and the right to choose in a free country.Scotland can either remain, semi-detached and impotent, as part of an increasingly insular Little Englander Tory Britain, bringing in its wake further austerity and diminished le chances for our young people, or Scots can vote for independence, just like our neighbours.Yes, there will be dficult choices, yes, there will be mistakes, but they will be our decisions to get right as we work for the prosperous, open and internationalist country that is within our grasp.I am delighted that our council will be investing nearly £. million to help keep Argyll and Bute going and growing.After relentless campaigning from myself and others it#s great to see, at long last, some substantial investment in our crumbling infrastructure.Building on investments made in previous years, an additional £. million will be invested to drive forward improvements and repairs to Argyll and Bute#s network of roads in rural, remote, island and urban communities, bringing the overall roads reconstruction budget to £ million for  .We are also investing more in active travel, in line with the council#s agreed priorities. This includes a further £, in enhancing and improving footpaths. This investment complements the current allocation of £, in green transport and travel.This recent Covid pandemic has highlighted more than ever the need to tackle our urban-rural ide. Even now, many of my constituents are paying primum prices for snail#s pace broadband speeds.That#s why £, is being invested in a Tackling Digital Exclusion Top-Up Fund # to support people, businesses and communities to access improved digital connections for social and commercial opportunities supporting communities and in some cases iniduals that are missing out on national programmes due to logistics and economies of scale.While this budget is not perfect and there will be challenges ahead as we start to recover from the ongoing global pandemic this is a massive step in the correct direction.Now my constituents across the Kintyre and the Islands ward will quite rightly want to see action, not more talking.So that means more help for our small businesses, improving our digital connectivity and substantial improvements to our roads which in so many areas are sadly approaching the point of no .Six years ago, I had a sudden and le-changing stroke. I’m not alone in this: stroke strikes every five minutes in the UK, and around . million survivors are living with its devastating effects.Despite this, research into stroke is severely underfunded. Just one per cent of the total UK public and third sector health research spend goes towards stroke research.The Stroke Association has launched a unique opportunity for stroke survivors and those who care for stroke survivors to have our say on the future of stroke research. Partnered with the James Lind Alliance, the charity will find out what matters to us most so research can make the biggest dference to our lives.With such limited funds for stroke research, worsened by the Covid- pandemic, it#s vital that we come together and make our voices heard.If you#re a stroke survivor, or you care for or work with someone affected by stroke, join me and speak up for stroke.Visit www.stroke.org.uk jla by March .

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A collapsed stretch of the leline road serving Skipness and the Arran ferry will be reinstated # but not before the new financial year in April.More than a year after the B collapsed near Claonaig ferry terminal, it has not been repaired and there is real concern the single track carriageway will collapse completely, leaving the village of Skipness cut off by road.This would mean no access for emergency vehicles, fuel supplies, agricultural deliveries, public and private transport, doctor and carer visits and Arran ferry traffic.One Skipness man said last week that it was #an impending disaster# and called on Argyll and Bute Council to carry out #immediate repairs and reinstatement of the only access to the village#.In January, the council said it had been #working hard to find a design solution to stabilise the B, which has been affected by landslips#, adding the Covid- pandemic delayed the project.The council realigned the road, but no engineering work has taken place to repair the collapsed section.Speaking in the wake of the   budget being set, council leader Robin Currie, one of three councillors for Kintyre and Islands, said: #I have been pressing for work on this road and it features in the roads capital reconstruction budget for the Mid Argyll, Kintyre and the Islandsarea for  , with an estimated allocation of £, for embankment stabilisation.#In the meantime, officers are looking at the best engineering options for how best to progress the work at Skipness.#Councillor Alastair Redman added: #I have been contacted by a large number of my justiably concerned constituents about this matter. The dinghy was then taken to Tayinloan.Fears that the flare signalled the ers were in serious trouble meant Islay leboat was launched and a rescue helicopter from Prestwick was scrambled.FIFTY YEARS AGOMarines scare: contact made with #missing# commandosCarradale was buzzing with excitement this week when it was discovered four Marine commandos had been missing for days in the hills of Kintyre.The Marines, who were taking part in an exercise, were to have reported back to a vessel berthed at Carradale harbour, to be taken back to the barracks.The original number of #missing# men had been , but eight gradually found their way back to the boat, an Admiralty MFV.Villagers were concerned about the safety of the Marines who were not accounted for.A Marine spokesman told the Courier at Carradale on Tuesday evening that four men were still #missing#. He was shown in great bloom and has been hired to Biggar and Peebles for the year and to Campbeltown District for .Carradale # a pretty weddingA marriage in anticipation of which local interest has been largely centred for several weeks was solemnised at Carradale United Free Church on the th ult., the contracting parties being Mr Archibald MB Crichton, Willow Bank, Albert Road, Gourock, and Miss Catherine C Mitchell, Carradale.The church was well filled by guests when the service commenced at the #solemn twilight hour#, and this scene was truly an impressive one when the principles arrived at the appointed time.The officiating clergymen were the Reverend George S McLeod and the Reverend JAA Baker.Mr Crichton was accompanied by Mr Alan Headridge as best man, while the role of bridesmaid was capably filled by Miss C Cook, who was attired in a charming creation of white crepe-de-chine.The bride#s dress was of white georgette over charmeuse with an inset yoke of silver tissue, trimmed with seed pearls and relieved with orange blossoms at the waist.After the church ceremony, the wedding guests, numbering over  couples, were sumptuously entertained in the adjacent spacious school room.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I shall leave John Newall to respond to Ron Wilson#s letter in last week#s Courier,he so wishes, but I cannot let that letter from the Kintyre SNP secretary pass without comment from me regarding some factual errors contained therein.Mr Newall is quite correct in his assertion that Scotland#s deficit will be a major stumbling block to an independent Scotland joining the EU, and whatever debt the UK may or may not have is neither here nor there with regard to this. Mr Wilson is trying to muddy the waters there.Whilst Mr Wilson is correct that Scotland cannot have debt , Scotland does have deficit, and the reason we know this is because the SNP-run Scottish Government tells us so in the annual Government Revenue and Expenditure, Scotlandbut Mr Wilson contradicts himself by going on to say that Scotland has a #notional debt# . Scotland has no debt. Scotland cannot have debt. Mr Wilson needs to realise that debt and deficit are two dferent things.With regard to HS, yes, Scotland pays a two per cent share of the total cost but will receive approximately . per cent back in Barnett consequentials. THAT is a very good deal for Scotland. London#s Crossrail  Not a single penny for that will be paid for by Scotland.Mr Wilson goes on to say that there is no #prohibition on independence votes#. Another error from him. Section  of The Scotland Act , the act which allowed us to have a devolved assembly and to which the then Scottish Office signed up, lays down the exact process required. We need permission from HMGov.Oh, and the notion that Scotland can abrogate the Treaty Of Union is also wrong. Whilst Westminster is a parliament of equals, it cannot of itself dissolve the Treaty of Union of which it was not itself a progenitor. That is the prerogative of the suspended national parliaments of England and Scotland, which will require to be recalled from suspension #in abeyance ad interim# where they legitimately reside at the present time. Only the recalled national parliaments of Scotland and England may re-negotiate the  Treaty of Union.I would take this opportunity to remind Mr Wilson of two things: we had a referendum in  and voted to stay in the UK, and he should really learn to live with that and in no election ever, General or Scottish, has the SNP garnered more than  per cent of the vote.The decision by Argyll and Bute Council to stop funding Kintyre Recycling Limited is perverse to say the least.No thought seems to have been given to the level and cost of the future support for the employees who will be thrown on the scrap-heap. Will that go to the social work department and will they get the same level of support as they do now No thought seems to have been given to the effect on the mental health of the employees # what support will be available and what budget will it come from How can the expenditure of a quarter of a million pounds be justied when the council is struggling for money and how long will it take to save this amount compared with the partial funding for Kintyre Recycling Limited It is shameful that only two of our local councillors are against vulnerable people being thrown on the scrap-heap when all three should be supporting their constituents.I am pleased to support the new business group set up to campaign for a quick and permanent solution for the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A.It’s now seven months since the landslide closed the A last summer. That should have been a wake-up call for the SNP Government, but all we#ve had since then is a failed attempt to protect the Old Military Road from landslides and talk of taking  years to solve the problem.This is just not good enough. We need urgent action now.Last week#s Courier letters page didn#t offer much hope. The SNP only wrote about independence, not the real issues facing us, such as the Rest and Be Thankful.The SNP Government should be concentrating on fixing the Rest and Be Thankful and recovering from the Covid pandemic, not spending its time plotting about independence.This Mother#s Day, school feeding charity Mary#s Meals would like to pay tribute to incredible women around the world.From the mums in the UK whose food has nourished us throughout our childhoods, including those who volunteer and fundraise for Mary#s Meals, to the women who cook and serve our daily meals for children in some of the world#s poorest countries, we celebrate them all.Mary#s Meals feeds more than . million hungry children in  countries every school day.That#s why I am asking your readers to send a Mary#s Meals gt card to the special women in their lives this Mother#s Day. For just £., it will feed a hungry child every day for an entire school year.Please visit marysmeals.org.uk mothersday to purchase your gt card or digital gt.I know I#d love itmy three lovely children gave me this special present for Mother#s Day.Launching its manesto ahead of the Scottish elections, the Stroke Association in Scotland is reminding people that stroke remains a clinical priority in Scotland amid the pandemic.Our Recoveries at Risk report last autumn highlighted the real-le impact of the Covid- pandemic on people recovering from a stroke.Health officials have been working to review evidence and define what #a progressive stroke service for Scotland# should look like. This will include improved stroke care bundle figures, improved stroke prevention measures, a national thrombectomy service and stroke-specic, person-centred rehabilitation.The charity is pleased that people affected by stroke will be included in the development of this work.A draft paper will be with the Scottish Government in the next few weeks. Whatever the outcome of May#s election, the Stroke Association in Scotland expects the next government to push this work on, and for a new, improved, progressive stroke service to be implemented.

title: scottish-rugby-legends-help-musselburgh-rfc-celebrate-centenary
story: Former Scotland internationalists ndash including brothers Gavin and Scott Hastings and Iain and Kenny Milne, John Jeffrey, Sean Lineen, Jim Calder and player coach Ian McGeechan ndash gave welcome contributions to a recent online celebration, while there was also a special message from Doddie Weir, who is battling motor neurone disease.Another guest of honour was current Scotland captain Stuart Hogg.The clubrsquos plans to host a formal dinner are on hold due to the Covid- pandemic but its -year history was covered in the successful and well-attended lsquovirtualrsquo event.Interesting stories and memories were shared by members, players, captains and presidents.Drew Johnston, club president, said: ldquoAlthough it has been a strange year, as a Musselburgh boy who has been part of the club for  years, I am greatly honoured to be president as we reach our centenary.Drew Johnston, president of Musselburgh RFC, displays bottles of the centenary real ale and ginHe added: ldquoI am confident that when rugby does , Musselburgh RFC will be able to continue to play its part at the top end of the club game in Scotland.ldquoWe have two senior XVs now, a social XV, strong youth and mini sections, and have forged close links with Musselburgh Grammar School, where we have a fledgling girlsrsquo team.ldquoWe are determined to continue to be a community club and a lsquoclub for allrsquo, with our key values of lsquoIntegrity, Inclusion and Respectrsquo to the fore.Musselburgh RFC will be sharing centenary videos which walk through its history, created by OsGood Films, on their social media s and website www.musselburghrfcJill Irving, treasurer, said: ldquoMusselburgh Sports Club was formed in  by locals who noticed a thirst for outdoor sports in the town and included sports such as football, athletics, cricket, golf and rugby.ldquoThe original minute book of the sports club documents the application and sanction of the formation of a rugby section on February , , and thus Musselburgh Rugby Football Club was established.ldquoThe first official match for MRFC was an away fixture against the Royal College of Surgeons on November , , which Musselburgh won -.ldquoFollowing long negotiations, the Earl of Wemyss agreed to lease seven acres of land to the sports club at Shirehaugh, by the banks of the River Esk and where Monktonhall Golf Club now resides.ldquoIn the s, the other sports such as football and cricket were all going their separate ways while the rugby club membership was strengthening, so in  the Musselburgh Sports Club was renamed the Musselburgh Rugby Football Club.ldquoThis was also the first year of the clubrsquos annual sevens tournament, a tradition which continues to this day.ldquoThe club moved to their current home at Stoneyhill in , shortly after they entered the Scottish Rugby Union as a full member in .ldquoThe facilities of the community centre were used and the clubhouse was officially opened in  with a celebratory half-centenary match against Hawick.ldquoChanging rooms were added in , and the clubrsquos st XV were promoted to League Division  in .ldquoThey ed to the top flight of Scottish club rugby, now called the Premiership, in , where they remain today.Jill added: ldquoThe club has prided itself on fielding local talent on the pitch coming through the ranks of its successful mini and youth programme, one of the oldest sections in Scotland, running coaching for players from P through to senior and now with a dedicated youth development officer within Musselburgh Grammar School.ldquoRelying heavily on volunteers to perform all the necessary roles needed to run, MRFC consistently delivers youth and senior rugby, a clubhouse facility with bar,facilities and catering on match days.ldquoThe club boasts a membership of over  people and has reignited connections with many local businesses through a recent and successful sponsorship drive. The centenary project of adding a gym to the clubhouse is now under way, and the club look forward to offering this new facility to players, members and the local community.The club has not allowed the pandemic to dampen its th birthday celebrations and launched special drinks over Christmas to herald the centenary year.Working closely with Hurly Burly Brewery at Inveresk Industrial Estate, three real ales have been named Shirehaugh, Stoneyhill and Butcherrsquos Apronto commemorate the clubrsquos history.The club also worked with one of its sponsors and supporters, Pickeringrsquos Gin, Edinburgh, to create a commemorative bottle of gin. title: 45-000-set-aside-help-reduce-inequalities-musselburgh-area
story: A total of pound, will fund the lsquoPeople Know How, Computer Delivery Learn Digitalrsquo project which will deliver  refurbished computers, laptops and tablets to help people in the area.A further pound, has been allocated to the East Lothian Play Association for lsquoPlayful Families Musselburghrsquo which will offer therapeutic play sessions in schools and communities.In relation to the digital initiative, work will take place with East Lothian Council, Third Sector organisations, community groups and NHS Lothian to ensure the equipment reaches those in need. Each recipient will be supported by a volunteer befriender.A spokesman for the area partnership said: ldquoThis funding will enable People Know How to build capacity and deliver a Musselburgh specic service. A team of staff will allocate time to the service and support and manage a team of volunteers, interns and placement students. As coronavirus restrictions are eased and we move into the recovery phase we will provide face to face support to people at locations within the communities making up the Musselburgh Area Partnership area.He added: ldquoWorsened by Covid-, isolation and loneliness and digital exclusion are growing problems for people in Musselburgh and the surrounding area. They will support people to discover the power of the internet and reconnect with their hobbies, passions, friends, and families, through the abundance of opportunities a digital device can offer.ldquoThey will work in a person-centred way ndash at the pace the person wants to go and on what is important to the person.ldquoPeople Know How have supported people with any number of issues that have been important to them from getting the best deal on their internet to learning to play a musical instrument online.ldquoThey aim to support every person with a befriender who will support them to discover and grow their digital confidence. From experience this can involve a couple of sessions to meeting twice a week for a year.The spokesperson explained that the focus of the lsquoPlayful Families Musselburghrsquo initiative recognises that many children have experienced anxiety, stress and loss throughout the period of Covid- restrictions and that the transitions back into nursery and school will be challenging for many. Families may be experiencing financial and emotional dficulties, impacting the whole family, he added.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThe Musselburgh Area Partnership has been actively looking at deliverable projects through key partners which will have a positive impact on reducing inequalities in a number of areas affecting our community.ldquoBoth these projects were presented at a recent meeting of the partnership and were subject to questioning by the members. Both projects were agreed by the partnership as valuable in supporting our community. We look forward to receiving updates on progress over the next year.

title: cockenzie-360-centre-gets-community-support
story: Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council has backed East Lothian Councilrsquos lsquovisionaryrsquo plan for the site since it was published nearly four years ago.The Cockenzie Masterplan was drawn up following public consultation at a cost of pound, but the local authority refused calls from the community council to adopt it, instead insisting it was a lsquovisionary documentrsquo.Four years on, the site, which is owned by the council, remains undeveloped, with the only approved plans for the land a controversial substation, branded a ldquogiant shed, which will allow Inch Cape Offshore Limited to bring power from an offshore windfarm onto the land to feed into the National Grid.And at a meeting this week, community council chairman Bryan Hickman said that the support appeared to have got the community nowhere.He said: ldquoWe have supported the masterplan over the years for this site and to a certain extent appear to be flogging a dead horse. It is not being adopted by the council.He was speaking as representatives of an alternative proposal for the site, the  Centre, attended the virtual meeting to discuss their ideas.: Eden-style project for CockenzieThe community-led project was sparked by Jill des Fresnes, who is employed by East Lothian Council to oversee Preston Seton Gosford heritage project Salt of the Earth.She told the meeting that she was inspired while walking at the site and admiring the view out to sea.She has been joined in the project by local artist Andrew Crummy, and other project members community councillor Shona Brash and Gareth Jones from the Waggonway Trust, also attended the meeting.Ms des Fresnes said that the aim of the  Centre was to create a green education centre like the Eden Project in Cornwall which would reflect the arearsquos heritage and culture, as well as looking forward.Among the ideas for the site would be giant statues, created by Mr Crummy, who has created a series of sculptures of women which would look out to sea and be large enough for people to go inside and climb.The project is described as having a creative vision similar to the Eden Project but will be firmly rooted in the idea of renewable green energy.Former Cockenzie Power Station siteIt describes the centre as being built in a rewilded area which brings together the beauty of the area, its arts and culture, and industrial heritage.The project remains at an early stage and the  Centre has approached East Lothian Council for funding support to carry out a feasibility study.Ms des Fresnes told the community council: ldquoIt is not just community, it will have to be a partnership between communities, the council, private companies and environmental groups.ldquoBut we have to make sure the communityis at the heart of it.The community council unanimously agreed to sht support previously given to the Cockenzie Masterplan to the  Centre project.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe masterplan for the former Cockenzie Power Station site was compiled following widespread community consultation."It was made clear from the very start of this process that that Masterplan would be a visionary document for the site based on the wishes and ideas of the local community and interested parties."Development of the site and wider surrounding area very much depends on whether it will be designated an area of national importance by the Scottish Government in their National Planning Framework NPF planning process, which is currently underway."

title: call-consultation-whether-haddingtons-new-20mph-speed-limit-made-permanent
story: The reduced speed limit throughout the town ndash and others in East Lothian ndash was brought in last year in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, chairman of Haddington and District Community Council, stressed the importance of members of the public having a say on whether the limits should remain in place.He said: ldquoNot everybody wanted a mph speed limit in Edinburgh when it was proposed. Now, it has got a mph speed limit with the Spaces for People initiative. Of course, it is not just East Lothian but Edinburgh and the other councils are looking at making things like that permanent.ldquoIrsquom not against a mph speed limit in certain places in the town, especially residential areas. But also there are blanket areas where they have covered everything in Haddington, which may or may not have required the mph limit.ldquoA consultation about that would seepeople are wanting it or not.ldquoI can see the huge benefits of a mph limit in places like Seggarsdean, Somnerfield and other small areas cars use as run-throughs.But Mr McEwan felt that there were other areas where the reduced speed limit was not necessary.He highlighted Dunbar Road as a potential route that might not require the lower speed limit due to the lack of pedestrian traffic compared with other areas in the town.However, he stressed it was important that people who lived or drove through certain areas of the town had the chance to give their view.He noted that there were areas of the town that he did not drive on a regular basis and therefore other members of the community would be better placed to add their views, while some streets which were not included in the mph limit, such as Whittingehame Drive, might benefit from a slower speed limit.The community councillor said: ldquoIt is up to the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo associations, the community groups and the community themselves to be asking these things.Questions were asked at the last meeting of the community council as to whether people stuck to the lower speed limit, particularly on long, straight stretches, such as West Road.Mr McEwan highlighted that some cars came with technology to set the speed they were travelling at but said the most effective way of ensuring vehicles stuck to the speed limit was through policing.Ward councillor Craig Hoy was among those at the virtual meeting of the community council.He said: ldquoI would assume it requires consultation [to make it permanent].A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe implementation of temporary mph limits in most of our larger towns and some villages, plus some temporary mph lsquobufferrsquo zones to support the mph areas, can be in place until March  as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People programme.ldquoThese measures are designed to improve health and wellbeing and ensure everyone is able to move around their local area safely while keeping to physical distancing requirements as we transition through and out of the Covid- pandemic.ldquoWe have received positive feedback from communities to keep and extend the new lower speed limits. If there is community support to make some or all of these permanent, a report would be taken to council for consideration. If such a report was approved, a traffic regulation order would be required, which can only be done by a statutory process, which includes full public consultation.

title: 3-harbours-arts-festival-take-place-online-year

title: church-ministers-virtual-climb-3-700-metres-help-preston-lodge-students
story: The Rev Dr Robin Hill, minister of Gladsmuir linked with Longniddry, has set himself the challenge of climbing  metres each morning for the  days of Lent to raise pound for the Preston Lodge High SchoolLearning Foundation.The foundation secured a grant earlier in the year for a substantial number of Chromebooks ndash but not enough to meet the scale of demand.Dr Hill, a trustee of the charity, said children were struggling to learn at home without up-to-date technology.He said: ldquoA Chromebook costs pound so, for a comparatively small investment, Preston Lodge can set up families with the le-changing resources they so urgently need.Unable to physically climb some of Scotlandrsquos finest mountains, Dr Hill has opted for an in-house alternative and will be climbing the stairs in his manse.He added: ldquoSo far, I have climbed the equivalent of the Efel Tower, the Sydney Tower and almost the Empire State Building, all on  stairs.ldquoThe main thing to remember each morning is to tie a double knot in my trainers ndash I donrsquot want to trip and fall.His virtual altitude goal of , feet exceeds the height of Scafell Pike, Snowdon and Ben Nevis combined.Dr Hill said he wanted to give back to the school that helped his children when they were students.His ultimate goal is to raise enough money to secure  Chromebook computers. Donations can be made to the Gladsmuir and Longniddry Parish Church  Lent Appeal.

title: two-mobile-coronavirus-testing-units-coming-east-lothian
story: The asymptomatic testing units aim to help identy positive cases and break chains of transmission.Members of the public who have no symptoms associated with Covid-, but who may be infectious and spreading the disease without knowing it, will be invited to take a test.The units have been provided by the Scottish Government and will be staffed by the Scottish Ambulance Service.Initially, the units will be at Prestonpans Community Centre and the Loch Centre in Tranent from Monday to Wednesday next week , am-pm.They will then move to the Port Seton Centre and the Mercat Bar and Grill in Whitecraig from next Thursdayuntil next Saturdaybetween the same times.After this, they will switch between the four communities every few days until March .The Scottish Ambulance Service has requested that everyone who attends one of the mobile testing units makes an advance booking. This can bedone onlineor by telephone on   .Bookings can be made from pm the day before at gov.uk get-coronavirus-test, clicking the lsquoget a free test onlinersquo option.When asked why you are booking a test, people are asked to select the option lsquomy local council or health protection team has asked me to get a test, even though I do not have symptomsrsquo.When attending the sites, people are asked to wear a face covering and follow physical distancing.People are also asked to dress appropriately for the weather, as during popular times you may have to wait to be tested.The locations have been identied on a targeted basis in co-operation with public health colleagues, using the most up-to-date data looking at virus prevalence.Further arrangements for asymptomatic community testing are being developed for potential rollout in the weeks ahead.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoWhile itrsquos great to see progress with the vaccination programme which offers a way out of this awful situation, the reality is that Covid- continues to present a signicant risk.ldquoNot everyone who has the virus will be showing symptoms, which means people could be spreading it without realising.ldquoThatrsquos why, by visiting a local asymptomatic testing facility, you can help your community, families and friends stay safe and slow down the spread of this devastating virus.ldquoSupport will be available for people who test positive and need to self-isolate and I would encourage as many people as possible to participate.ldquoIt continues to be important to continue observing FACTS ndash wear face coverings, avoid crowds, clean hands, observe two-metre distancing, and self-isolate and book a testyou have symptoms.ldquoAnd the all-important lsquostay at homersquo message is still in place, including avoiding non-essential travel.ldquoThe combination of testing and following the title: changes-lockdown-rules-friday---need-know
story: Addressing MSPs in the Scottish Parliament, Ms Sturgeon said that four of the current rules were set to change, three of them from Friday.Due to decreasing cases and the ongoing vaccine rollout, from Friday up to four adults from two households will be allowed to meet outdoors for social and recreational purposes, as well as essential exercise.As well as in outdoor public places, people will be able to meet in back gardens and only go inside a houseit is essential, such as to go to the back garden or use a toilet.A similar change affects children aged -. Again, four people will be able to meet outside but it does not have to be from two households.Also from Friday, outdoor non-contact sports and group exercise will be able to take place.This includes both adults and children andis restricted to a limit of  people.There will be some flexibility to the travel rules to allow children to take part in outdoor group exercise and to ensure they are not excluded.The final change, to start on March , relates to communal worship.From this date, communal worship will be able to resume, with limits increased from  to  should the building allow this with two-metre social distancing.Ms Sturgeon called the changes "modest but important" and that while Scotland was "firmly on the right path" she could "not afford" to take her "foot off the brake too soon".She said:"In recent weeks, we have seen a signicant fall in new cases, deaths and hospital admissions, and the vaccination programme is progressing beyond our initial expectations."All of this is excellent news and provides strong grounds for hope, but that hope must also be balanced by caution."The changes announced today, while modest, are important and are designed to help peoplersquos health and wellbeing by enabling group exercise and allowing more social interaction. They will also let children see more of their friends and exercise and play more normally."With continued progress, we believe the reopening of places of worship can be achieved relatively safely and will hopefully enable more people to draw strength, comfort and inspiration from acts of collective worship."I expect that further, more substantial changes will be possible in the weeks ahead, and I will set out as much detail as I can about that in Parliament next week."If the data allows us to relax more restrictions more quickly than we have previously indicated, we will not hesitate to do so."We all have a part to play in keeping case numbers down while the vaccinators do their work, children get back to school and we all take tentative but firm steps back to le as we once knew it, so please continue to stay within the rules and follow the FACTS advice."

story: Concern over cars driving through Bolton Muir Wood, near Gford, as new owners of the  plots accessed huts led to East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Review Body rejecting the first application for the site.The application by Joe Tree was, councillors were told, likely to be the first of a number after the wood was sold in separate lots.And their legal adviser confirmed that approving the first hut application would make it more likely others would be granted planning permission.Councillor Jeremy Findlay raised concerns that there was no way to restrict the number of huts on each of the plots sold, adding: ldquoIt is possible it could turn into a holiday park by stealth. recommended that the review body grant planning permission for the hut, which they said did not breach the councilrsquos policy against new development in the country.Councillor Neil Gilbert backed the officers, saying that while he had concerns about cars in the woods, he could see no reason to object.Mr Hampshire, however, rejected the recommendation, saying that the application would have a or four trailers on it.ldquoWe could end up with potentially hundreds of people living in the woods.Mr Hampshire was backed by Mr Findlay as the appeal was rejected by two votes to one.

story: No. Hotel  Bistro is spending more than pound, on upgrading its outdoor eating and drinking area, utilising old shipping containers and creating more covered seating.Owner Sean McCashey said: ldquoIt is evident that in , like , having outdoor eating and drinking areas is going to be key to our survival.ldquoOutdoor areas are more desirable and popular than indoor ones as people feel safer and can be more relaxed.ldquoIn , the outside eating and drinking area at the rear of the hotel created more job opportunities, fulfilled by local people. title: musselburgh-surgery-reveals-high-uptake-coronavirus-vaccine
story: The practice ndash which has now vaccinated more than , people ndash says that many patients praised the efficient way the vaccine clinics were being run by the team.A huge  per cent of patients aged - rolled up their sleeves to get their first jag, along with  per cent of shielders and  per cent of patients aged over  ndash all substantially higher than the initial  per cent expected by the Scottish Government when the vaccine programme first began.Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner at the practice based in Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, said: ldquoWersquore delighted that so many of our patients accepted our invitation to have their first dose of the Covid vaccine.He added: ldquoAge is a signicant risk factor for Covid so itrsquos great news that such a large proportion of our oldest patients ndash and our vulnerable shielding patients ndash are now on track to be immunised against this disease.The vaccination team at Riverside Medical PracticeldquoItrsquos so important that everyone sticks to the mask wearing, social distancing and good hand hygiene but we should be optimistic about the success of the vaccination programme so far.The practice puts a lot of its success in terms of vaccine uptake down to its policy of personally contacting all eligible patients by phone to invite them to their appointment.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoWe feel that a conversation with someone at a practice may increase vaccine uptake over and above the uptake in response to letters or text messages.ldquoOur GPs had quite a few conversations with people who wanted some reassurance about the vaccine and wersquore so pleased that, with many people, the information we gave them about the safety and efficacy of the vaccine gave them the confidence they needed to go ahead and book their appointment. Our letter follow-up programme also led to some patients from harder-to-reach groups, such as non-English speakers, booking an appointment.The practice ndash East Lothianrsquos biggest ndash will be contacting shielders and everyone aged  and over about their second doses once they receive further instruction from the Government and health board, and have more information on vaccine supplies.Patients are asked to wait to be contacted about their second dose appointment to make sure the practice phone line remains free for people with urgent health concerns.
